//comment0: This is the format of the metadata of your raw table.
//comment1: We focus on one table first, i.e.input: a messy table, output: a clean table.
//comment2: The .json file should contain two parts, for specific attributes & for the whole table, as shown below.

For specific attributes:.//comment3: Use attributes name as keys, and values type=object.
For specific attributes:.//comment4: The followings are available key-value pairs in values and their usags.

null.dc: Delete this column if containing null, type=str.
null.ra: Replace null by the average of the rest, type=str.
null.rn: Replace null by a random number follows the normal distribution, type=str.
null.rm: Replace null by the mode of the rest, type=str.
null.rd: Replace null by rd, an input number, type=number.
null.rs: Replace null by rs, an input string, type=str.

For the whole table:.//comment5: The followings are available key-value pairs and their usages.

null.ra: Replace null by the average of the rest, type=str.
null.rn: Replace null by a random number follows the normal distribution, type=str.
null.rm: Replace null by the mode of the rest, type=str.
null.rd: Replace null by rd, an input number, type=number.

For the whole table:.rs: Replace null by rs, an input string, type=str.

sortby.[{'attributes name' : 'order'}]: Sort by the array of attributes with order='acs' or 'desc', type=array.

cat.'new attribute name' : ['attributes name: Concatenate the array of attriutes into one attribute and assign a new name, type=object.

trim.['attributes names']: Keep them and drop the rest attributes, type=array.
